articles.headline: How Much Car Do You Buy to Keep Your Teenager Safe?
articles.snippet: Modern safety features in cars can help drivers avoid accidents, but parents don’t have to buy a new car to get those systems. Many used cars have them.
articles.abstract: Modern safety features in cars can help drivers avoid accidents, but parents don’t have to buy a new car to get those systems. Many used cars have them.
articles.lead_paragraph: So your teenager needs a car. Or maybe you need the teenager to have a car so you can get out of the chauffeuring business.

articles.headline: Martin Shkreli Resigns From Turing Pharmaceuticals
articles.snippet: Mr. Shkreli was charged with fraud this week related to activities at a hedge fund he ran and at an earlier pharmaceutical company.
articles.abstract: Mr. Shkreli was charged with fraud this week related to activities at a hedge fund he ran and at an earlier pharmaceutical company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli has resigned as chief executive of Turing Pharmaceuticals after his arrest on securities fraud charges, the company announced on Friday.

articles.headline: Wind Power Spreads Through Turbines for Lease
articles.snippet: United Wind is applying the rooftop solar approach to wind, installing and maintaining wind turbine systems at little to no upfront cost to the customer.
articles.abstract: United Wind is applying the rooftop solar approach to wind, installing and maintaining wind turbine systems at little to no upfront cost to the customer.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULLY, N.Y. — Three years ago, Ed Doody and his brothers, Kevin and Rich, installed a wind turbine at the dairy farm they operate here, looking to cut electric bills. They were so happy with the results that each got a turbine for his home, visible from the farm, which overlooks rolling hills and orchards.

articles.headline: Regulators Tamp Down on Mergers of Hospitals
articles.snippet: For the third time in recent weeks, the Federal Trade Commission is seeking to scuttle a proposed hospital merger.
articles.abstract: For the third time in recent weeks, the Federal Trade Commission is seeking to scuttle a proposed hospital merger.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the latest sign that federal regulators are uneasy about the flurry of proposed health care mergers taking place, the Federal Trade Commission said on Friday that it planned to block the combination of two large Illinois hospital groups.

articles.headline: Internet Firms Urged to Limit Work of Anwar al-Awlaki
articles.snippet: The inflammatory videos and bomb-making instructions of Anwar al-Awlaki have turned up as a powerful influence in terrorism investigations.
articles.abstract: The inflammatory videos and bomb-making instructions of Anwar al-Awlaki have turned up as a powerful influence in terrorism investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In case after terrorism case, from the Fort Hood, Tex., shootings to the Boston Marathon bombing and now to the slaughter in San Bernardino, Calif., the inflammatory videos and bomb-making instructions of Anwar al-Awlaki, easily accessible on the Internet, have turned up as a powerful influence.

articles.headline: The Weinstein Brothers Have Oscar Gold. Now They Need Cash.
articles.snippet: Investors who put their money behind the brothers in their venture 10 years ago are itching for more than award-worthy entertainment. They want a payout.
articles.abstract: Investors who put their money behind the brothers in their venture 10 years ago are itching for more than award-worthy entertainment. They want a payout.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harvey Weinstein was in motion.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Campaign Lags in Mobilizing Iowa Caucus Voters
articles.snippet: Despite continued strength in polls, organizers have fallen behind some of their own benchmarks with six weeks to go, possibly imperiling chances of victories in early nominating states.
articles.abstract: Despite continued strength in polls, organizers have fallen behind some of their own benchmarks with six weeks to go, possibly imperiling chances of victories in early nominating states.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Donald J. Trump has dominated much of this political season, excited an often-ignored part of the electorate, filled huge arenas with followers and upended the rules of how modern campaigns are run.

articles.headline: In Democratic Debate, Hillary Clinton’s Focus Is on G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders put aside the hard feelings over the breach of her voter data, while they and Martin O’Malley had heated exchanges on foreign policy and corporate America.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders put aside the hard feelings over the breach of her voter data, while they and Martin O’Malley had heated exchanges on foreign policy and corporate America.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton largely looked past her Democratic rivals in Saturday night’s debate, instead repeatedly assailing the Republican field, led by Donald J. Trump. She called Mr. Trump a threat to the nation’s safety, saying he was fast “becoming ISIS’ best recruiter.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Theranos Founder Faces a Test of Technology, and Reputation
articles.snippet: Elizabeth Holmes built Theranos into a company valued at $9 billion, with help from some powerful family connections, but its successes have been fleeting.
articles.abstract: Elizabeth Holmes built Theranos into a company valued at $9 billion, with help from some powerful family connections, but its successes have been fleeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: It should have been Theranos’s moment to shine.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Inside the Billion-Dollar Battle for Puerto Rico’s Future
articles.snippet: The impoverished island turned to hedge funds to stave off collapse. Now someone has to pay.
articles.abstract: The impoverished island turned to hedge funds to stave off collapse. Now someone has to pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: The money poured in by the millions, then by the hundreds of millions, and finally by the billions. Over weak coffee in a conference room in Midtown Manhattan last year, a half-dozen Puerto Rican officials exhaled: Their cash-starved island had persuaded some of the country’s biggest hedge funds to lend them more than $3 billion to keep the government afloat.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Mahler and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: U.S. and Cuba at Odds Over Exodus of the Island’s Doctors
articles.snippet: An escape route was set up by the United States government, under a 2006 program that offers American residency to Cuban medical workers posted overseas.
articles.abstract: An escape route was set up by the United States government, under a 2006 program that offers American residency to Cuban medical workers posted overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he came of age in Cuba, José Angel Sánchez enrolled in medical school for the usual reasons: to help the sick and to make a better living than most in his destitute eastern town. But he had another motive, too.
articles.byline: By Victoria Burnett and Frances Robles

articles.headline: In ISIS Strategy, U.S. Weighs Risk to Civilians
articles.snippet: As President Obama pledged to intensify the anti-Islamic State campaign, he acknowledged the challenges in targeting militants who, in Raqqa, Syria, and elsewhere, inhabit the same spaces as civilians.
articles.abstract: As President Obama pledged to intensify the anti-Islamic State campaign, he acknowledged the challenges in targeting militants who, in Raqqa, Syria, and elsewhere, inhabit the same spaces as civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, the United States military has known that the Islamic State uses the city hall in Raqqa, Syria, as an administrative center and a dormitory for scores of fighters. Some American officials even believe that Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the group’s leader, may have been in the building at times.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: U.S. Support of Gay Rights in Africa May Have Done More Harm Than Good
articles.snippet: American money and diplomacy have opened opportunities for gay rights in Africa, but they have also made gay men and lesbians more visible and more vulnerable, critics say.
articles.abstract: American money and diplomacy have opened opportunities for gay rights in Africa, but they have also made gay men and lesbians more visible and more vulnerable, critics say.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Suspicious neighbors and landlords pry into their private lives. Blackmailers hunt for victims on the social media sites they use to meet others of the same sex. Police officers routinely stop them to search for incriminating images and chats on their cellphones.

articles.headline: An Old-Media Empire, Axel Springer Reboots for the Digital Age
articles.snippet: The German publishing giant has snapped up stakes in online media companies, pivoted its news operations to cater to mobile readers and given its senior managers a crash course in start-up culture.
articles.abstract: The German publishing giant has snapped up stakes in online media companies, pivoted its news operations to cater to mobile readers and given its senior managers a crash course in start-up culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Mathias Döpfner, chief executive of Axel Springer, and a handful of his top managers first set their sights on the United States three years ago, it was with notebooks in hand, rather than checkbooks.

articles.headline: Rates Are Going Up. What Could Go Wrong?
articles.snippet: Having raised rates this month for the first time in nearly a decade, the Federal Reserve does not have to look far for real-world examples of what to do if plans go awry.
articles.abstract: Having raised rates this month for the first time in nearly a decade, the Federal Reserve does not have to look far for real-world examples of what to do if plans go awry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fire or ice?

articles.headline: Hospitality and Gambling Interests Delay Closing of Billion-Dollar Tax Loophole
articles.snippet: Lobbyists recently swooped in to add 54 words to a tax and spending bill of more than 2,000 pages that temporarily preserved a loophole sought by the hotel, restaurant and gambling industries, and billionaire Wall Street investors.
articles.abstract: Lobbyists recently swooped in to add 54 words to a tax and spending bill of more than 2,000 pages that temporarily preserved a loophole sought by the hotel, restaurant and gambling industries, and billionaire Wall Street investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the span of a mere 11 days this month, $1 billion in future federal tax payments vanished.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Liz Moyer

articles.headline: Regulations, Doubts and Concerns May Thwart Railway Mergers
articles.snippet: Consolidations in the ’90s led to lost cargo, derailments and billions of dollars lost, spurring rules on acquisitions. But these rules aren’t slowing Canadian Pacific’s pursuit of Norfolk Southern.
articles.abstract: Consolidations in the ’90s led to lost cargo, derailments and billions of dollars lost, spurring rules on acquisitions. But these rules aren’t slowing Canadian Pacific’s pursuit of Norfolk Southern.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to railroad consolidation, most opponents hark back to the mid-1990s, when a series of mergers at the time were blamed for lost cargo, derailments, death and billions of dollars lost by businesses and taxpayers.

articles.headline: As Downloads Take Over, a Turning Point for the Video Game Industry
articles.snippet: Faster broadband speeds and bigger hard drives in game consoles are changing the way the video game business works.
articles.abstract: Faster broadband speeds and bigger hard drives in game consoles are changing the way the video game business works.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — This holiday season could be remembered as a digital watershed for the games business, the moment when the old way of selling video games — on discs in boxes — finally gave way to downloads.

articles.headline: Behind the Black Flag: The Recruitment of an ISIS Killer
articles.snippet: Since the Syrian rebel leader Hassan Aboud joined ISIS, taking with him fighters and weapons, he has been behind a sprawling mix of battlefield action and crime.
articles.abstract: Since the Syrian rebel leader Hassan Aboud joined ISIS, taking with him fighters and weapons, he has been behind a sprawling mix of battlefield action and crime.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hassan Aboud’s practiced baritone belied the malevolence in his words.

articles.headline: A Plan to Rank ‘Just’ Companies Aims to Close the Wealth Gap
articles.snippet: The hedge fund billionaire Paul Tudor Jones II is working with the self-help star Deepak Chopra to rate how companies treat workers, society and the environment.
articles.abstract: The hedge fund billionaire Paul Tudor Jones II is working with the self-help star Deepak Chopra to rate how companies treat workers, society and the environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul Tudor Jones II, the hedge-fund billionaire, has a plan to reduce income inequality. He wants to rate companies on their probity, not their profits.

articles.headline: Shenzhen, Embodying China’s Growth, Falls Risk to It
articles.snippet: China’s rapid construction of new buildings, and the short life of many of those structures, have long created problems with unregulated dumping of construction waste.
articles.abstract: China’s rapid construction of new buildings, and the short life of many of those structures, have long created problems with unregulated dumping of construction waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — Rescuers searched for survivors in a sea of red mud on Monday, a day after dirt and construction debris engulfed dozens of buildings in this city in southern China, the latest of several man-made disasters in recent years to lay bare the perils of the nation’s rapid growth.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Austin Ramzy

articles.headline: Higher Interest Rates Lower Expectations in Emerging Economies
articles.snippet: As in many emerging economies, companies in Indonesia gorged on cheap debt to fund expansion. Now they face higher interest rates on top of a plummeting rupiah and a commodity slump.
articles.abstract: As in many emerging economies, companies in Indonesia gorged on cheap debt to fund expansion. Now they face higher interest rates on top of a plummeting rupiah and a commodity slump.
articles.lead_paragraph: PANGKALAN KERINCI, Indonesia — In this company town where acacia and palm oil trees stretch for miles, the Indonesian conglomerate Royal Golden Eagle is bracing for impact.

articles.headline: Martin Shkreli Is Removed as C.E.O. From Another Company, KaloBios
articles.snippet: KaloBios Pharmaceuticals is a California biotechnology company that Mr. Shkreli gained control of in November.
articles.abstract: KaloBios Pharmaceuticals is a California biotechnology company that Mr. Shkreli gained control of in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli, who was arrested last week on securities fraud charges, has been ousted from his second pharmaceutical company.
